results.content: The first part of the course was good for me because it did not use Enterprise versions or Team cloud services. I found the course to be much less interesting and less useful the further it progressed. And sorry to say, but the author's accent was very tiring to listen to and difficult to understand. If I could take a similar course from a native English speaker, I would.

results.content: It taught me how to install the visual studio

results.content:
the pacing is ok but it's jarring that the presenter doesn't seem to understand IT terms. Saying 'emm bee' for megabytes and carefully pronouncing Eye. Dee. Eee. for IDE, this leads to a somewhat stilted experience
The Presenter for the second part is much more knowledgeable and has a relaxed style, the sequence also shows more 'real world' examples.

results.content: The first part, the part about installing and using Visual Studio for the first time, was great. I wasn't interested in the "What's new with C#" part, so I skipped that section -- no big deal. There's no section on actually building and running programs. Instead, the course goes straight into debugging. Really? And the debugging narrator has impressive credentials, but has too thick of an accent to be a good narrator.
results.content_html: The first part, the part about installing and using Visual Studio for the first time, was great. results.content:
This course was supposed to be about the features of and how to use the Visual Studio IDE.  The course has two sections and neither one came close to those advertised claims.  Section one was basically installing and new features of C#.

Section two was voiced by a guy with an incomprehensible thick accent making it worthless.

Very disappointing.....

Very disappointing.....
